tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out the best way to take care of this period pain.

The approach would be to use an anti inflammatory pain reliever to not only reduce the pain, but reduce the amount of bleeding.

It is always better to take the pills day before the period starts to prevent the pain from building up.

With this approach in mind, see what is recommended below.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/06/2016

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to collapse contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header:
Let's see how to take care of this insect bite.

Know that we are talking about insect bites and stings that caused a mild reaction confined to the area of the bite.

If you are having a severe reaction to the insect bite, seek emergency room visit.

Since most insect bites cause itching and swelling, we will take a look at what is available over the counter to take care of this.

We will also figure out what to do in case there are other symptoms like pain or blisters.

With this in mind, use the search field below to search for an insect and see what is available over the counter to take care of the bites.

mode.1: Self-care recommendations for bedbugs bites are discussed below. But you must have pest control get rid of these bedbugs to be successful.
mode.2: Remedies available over-the-counter for bee stings are discussed below.
mode.3: Let's see how to take care of this black fly bites.
mode.4: Remedies for chigger bites available over-the-counter are discussed below.
mode.5:
Let's figure out how to take care of this fireants bites.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.6:
Let's find what to use over-the-counter for these flea bites.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.7: Over-the-counter recommendations for mosquito bites are discussed below.
mode.8:
Let's see what to use for insect bites over-the-counter.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.9:
Let's see how to take care of this moth irritation.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.10:
Let's see what to use over-the-counter for this spider bite.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.11:
Recommendations for tick bites available over-the-counter are discussed below.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.12:
Let's see how to take care of this wasp bites over-the-counter.

 

Need treatment overview entry here

tabs.header_iregular:
Article currently being updated and reviewed by the pharmacist.
Please check back later.

This assumes you are looking at a minor skin rash.

A rash can be caused by many things. It is important you followed the link to appropriate topics suggested for you before you got to this stage.

For instance, if the rash is caused by a ringworm, you will need an antifungal cream, if due to poison ivy, there is a specific management process for that, if it is an allergic reaction, the best bet would be using an antihistamine cream or tablets. 

The rash that will be talked about here is something like a rash you got on contact with something or heat rash.

With this in mind, see what is recommended below to help with a skin rash.
